<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>Hope you enjoyed your extra hour of sleep, because of course that comes with a major asterisk: The sun sets in NYC at 4:45pm today.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Many of us in the Northern Hemisphere are about to enter a punishing stretch of darkness. So how to cope? Maybe we can borrow a page from the residents of Tromsø, Norway. In this city 200 miles north of the Arctic Circle, the sun doesn’t rise <em>at all</em> from November to January.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The folks of Tromsø show us that the best way to endure winter is to not endure it all—but to embrace it. Stanford psychologist Kari Leibowitz, who spent time in Tromsø, calls this having a <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/07/the-norwegian-town-where-the-sun-doesnt-rise/396746/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Wintertime Mindset</a>—an attitude that says, “Sure it’s cold and dark and I have no idea what time it is...but hey, I’m sipping a foamy latte with friends and am about to make a snowman.” The Norwegians even have a term for describing this feeling of cozy togetherness: <em>koselig</em>, a relative of the popular Danish term <em>hygge</em>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The concept of koselig is so potent that, in her research, Leibowitz found that as you go even farther north in Norway and encounter even more darkness, people have a significantly more positive winter mindset.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">As the Norwegians like to say, “There’s no such thing as bad weather, only bad clothes.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—<em>Neal Freyman</em></p>
</div>
</div>
</td>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/icebreakers-with-maria-shriver-and-patrick-schwarzenegger?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
Icebreakers with...Maria Shriver and Patrick Schwarzenegger
</a>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/icebreakers-with-maria-shriver-and-patrick-schwarzenegger?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Maria Shriver and Patrick Schwarzenegger holding MOSH bars" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/aafed71556bd681c689b155385655748cee796fb-4240x2384.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;"></p>
</a>
<small>
<em>Interwoven Media</em>
</small>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When Patrick Schwarzenegger moved back in with his mom, journalist and former First Lady of California Maria Shriver, during the pandemic, they decided to tackle two big projects: 1) watch all of <em>Yellowstone</em> and 2) launch a company.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The duo created a brain health brand, <a href="https://moshlife.com/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">MOSH</a>, to educate consumers about the most important part of your body (surprise: It’s not your delts). MOSH launched its first product (and promptly sold out of), protein bars, on September 21—World Alzheimer’s Day—and a portion of the proceeds will be donated to gender-based brain health research.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We chatted with Maria and Patrick about working with family and their new brain food.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Why did you decide to launch a snack brand?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Maria:</em> I've been involved in Alzheimer's research and prevention for two decades, and everywhere that I travel, people always say to me, “Do you have anything to eat? I've read your books, I've seen your documentaries, give me something to eat.” And I'm a protein bar fanatic. But every protein bar gave me a headache or a stomachache. And then my son, who's done a lot of work in the health and wellness space, said, “You should make your own bar to raise money for research and educate people about brain health.” And I was like, oh, I don't think I could do that. I'm too old. And he said, but I'll help you. And here we are.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Are there any other brands you look up to?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Patrick: </em>One of the holy grails, when we were creating this company, was Paul Newman and Newman's Own because he did such a good job of going into different spaces, from salad dressings to lemonade to iced teas to all kinds of different products.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What have you learned from working with a family member?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Maria:</em> I think it's a really great way to learn about what's going on in the world. Working with people who are young keeps you curious, keeps you vital, and keeps you energized. I think Patrick’s generation learns from my generation and vice versa.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Is there a piece of advice you think is outdated in the business world?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Patrick [to Maria]:</em> When you first had this idea, a lot of people were saying that no one really cares about the older market, and we don't think that stands true.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Maria: </em>I think that the boomers—and I'm a boomer—are redefining aging. Madison Avenue, so to speak, has not kept up with who we are and what we want. And so I think that that's a big, huge market</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There is a whole world out there of people who are thriving, working, and creating. Frank Gehry is 97 years of age, and he's designing the most incredible buildings in the world. Warren Buffett is at the top of his game, and he's 91.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>
</div>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/make-it-work-instilling-better-work-manners?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
Is It Bad Etiquette or Bad Performance?
</a>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/make-it-work-instilling-better-work-manners?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;"></p>
</a>
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>A new hire started on my team and I'm worried about their etiquette. They leave themselves unmuted on Zoom, often interrupting the speaker, they don't answer when called on by name, they don’t engage during 1:1 trainings, they have poor email communication—you get the picture. How do I go about communicating with them that they need to improve their etiquette, without hurting their feelings?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>–EtiquetteSOS in Los Angeles</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">At first blush, I didn’t think I’d be rolling up my sleeves for this one. As far as the unwritten rules of society are concerned, I typically come up an RSVP late and a dessert fork short. Besides, etiquette guidance is famously Miss Manners’s territory, and I’d like to think I know my place in the advice column universe.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The thing is, I’m not convinced that what you’re dealing with here is simply a lack of “etiquette.” If you work in LA, scheduling a late afternoon meeting with an East Coast colleague may be considered poor etiquette. Not being engaged in that meeting, and in fact being disruptive, is a performance issue. Similarly, while we might debate things like the art of the signoff (btw, you’ve inspired my latest, below), generally “poor email communication” is a matter of effectiveness, not merely politeness or convention.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Be it around etiquette or execution, the feedback you provide should be specific and actionable. Avoid making broad characterizations of their behavior (e.g., “disruptive,” “unengaged”) and instead focus on the specific examples that you’ve observed—what did you see? How did it impact the work environment? And what should it look like next time? Not only are you less likely to hurt feelings this way, but you’re also establishing measurable guidelines for what you expect to see going forward.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It often feels like an uncomfortable reality of leadership, but behavioral coaching is essential to the morale of your team and the preservation of work culture. Left unchecked, you’re likely to find yourself having to navigate more turbulent waters ahead.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">SOS (Signing off, Shane)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Write in here</a>. And if you’re super interested in how people deal with people, <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/hr/subscribe?utm_campaign=hr_in_morningbrew_sundays&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=crosspromo" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">check out HR Brew</a>.</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
WORK
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/some-states-are-loosening-child-labor-laws-to-put-younger-teens-to-work?email={{profile.email}}" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank">
Kids At Work
</a>
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/some-states-are-loosening-child-labor-laws-to-put-younger-teens-to-work?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A scene from Arrested Development, George Michael works in the frozen banana stand" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2aa47dde8a0375096346d06ff818015f00c66394-670x377.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;"></p>
</a>
<small>
<em>FOX</em>
</small>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In terms of trends coming back in style this season, we gotta be honest: We were thinking more corduroy, less child labor.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Amid hiring and retention woes, US companies have been setting their sights on the youths.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span>Teenage employment hit 32% this summer, its highest level </span><span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/law/2021/nov/02/child-labor-laws-weakened-us-industries-teens?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">since 2008</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
<li><span>Unemployment for 16- to 19-year-olds fell below the rate for 20- to 24-year-olds—for the first time in recorded US history.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And lawmakers in several states have been pushing to relax existing child labor laws.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Relax what now?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">A Wisconsin bill extending the legal working hours of kids ages 14 and 15 was approved by the state Senate in late October. Currently, under the federal Fair Labor Standards Act, these kids are legally permitted to work between 7am and 7pm from Labor Day until May 31, and until 9pm from June 1 until Labor Day. Community pools need their night swim lifeguards, after all.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If signed into law, Wisconsin’s SB332 would allow these younger teens to work between 6am and 9:30pm on days preceding school, and between 6am and 11pm on days not preceding school.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">State senators in Ohio introduced a <a href="https://legiscan.com/OH/bill/SB251/2021?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">similar bill</a> that would allow pre-driving-age teens to work until 9pm during the school year (7pm is the current cutoff).</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px"><li>
<span><strong>Don't call it child labor, though:</strong></span><span> a 2011 Wisconsin bill replaced all mentions of the term in employment statutes with the nicer-sounding, “employment of minors.”</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Critics say the bills are an example of the lengths employers and lawmakers will go to in order to avoid meeting the greater pay demands of the pandemic-era labor force. “Anything but increasing wages,” <a href="https://twitter.com/Taniel/status/1452074439978491907?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tweeted</a> journalist Daniel Nichanian.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">It’s not just the local ice cream shop</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Big names in Corporate America are ramping up the hiring of Americans born post-2005. A Wendy’s franchisee who owns 76 restaurants told the Pennsylvania Tribune that he’s employed about 500 14- and 15-year-olds since the summer. According to Indeed, the <a href="https://www.indeed.com/cmp/Wendy's/salaries/Crew-Member?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">average hourly wage</a> of a Wendy’s crew member is $9.51.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Signs advertising the hiring of eighth- and ninth graders at McDonald’s locations around the country have <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/business-58414597?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made headlines</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/JoshuaPotash/status/1453746545401204740?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1453746545401204740%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.commondreams.org%2Fnews%2F2021%2F11%2F02%2Frather-pass-wage-increases-gop-legislatures-move-weaken-child-labor-laws" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">struck a nerve</a> on social media. A sign asking parents if their 14-year-olds “need a job??” posted by a <a href="https://twitter.com/partynextweexnd/status/1392523095450206208?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1392523095450206208%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Fmcdonalds-trying-to-hire-teens-with-labor-shortage-2021-8" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Burger King</a> restaurant also went viral (in the bad way).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Supporters of loosening child labor laws cite the value of hard work and how workforce demands are changing when arguing for such measures. In a letter to the Wisconsin State Assembly, a couple who owns three small businesses wrote, “There needs to be some regulation on child labor, but...there needs to be some reconsideration for what is practical, necessary, and realistic.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">On the flip side, <a href="https://www.washington.edu/news/2011/02/09/working-more-than-20-hours-a-week-in-high-school-can-harm-grades-uw-researcher-finds/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">studies show</a> that working 20+ hours a week while in high school can have a negative impact on behavior and academics.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Debra Cronmiller, the executive director of the League of Women Voters of Wisconsin, told The Guardian, “The notion that we would be solving some economic turmoil by allowing the expansion of child labor hours is, at best, ridiculous, and at worst, very detrimental to young people.”—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that doesn’t want that extra hour of sleep, thankyouverymuch. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>

The 6,615 square-foot Barbie Dream House in beautiful Show Low, Arizona, about a 3-hour drive east from Phoenix, comes with much more than an updated kitchen and a forest view. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>4 beds, 5 bathrooms</span></li>
<li><span>9-stall horse stable with a dog training loft</span></li>
<li><span>Guesthouse</span></li>
<li><span>3 decks + 2 balconies for outside time without having to put your shoes on</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to say “to heck with daylight savings time!”?</p>

style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eHope you enjoyed your extra hour of sleep, because of course that comes with a major asterisk: The sun sets in NYC at 4:45pm today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMany of us in the Northern Hemisphere are about to enter a punishing stretch of darkness. So how to cope? Maybe we can borrow a page from the residents of Tromsø, Norway. In this city 200 miles north of the Arctic Circle, the sun doesn’t rise \u003cem\u003eat all\u003c/em\u003e from November to January.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe folks of Tromsø show us that the best way to endure winter is to not endure it all—but to embrace it. Stanford psychologist Kari Leibowitz, who spent time in Tromsø, calls this having a \u003ca href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/07/the-norwegian-town-where-the-sun-doesnt-rise/396746/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWintertime Mindset\u003c/a\u003e—an attitude that says, “Sure it’s cold and dark and I have no idea what time it is...but hey, I’m sipping a foamy latte with friends and am about to make a snowman.” The Norwegians even have a term for describing this feeling of cozy togetherness: \u003cem\u003ekoselig\u003c/em\u003e, a relative of the popular Danish term \u003cem\u003ehygge\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe concept of koselig is so potent that, in her research, Leibowitz found that as you go even farther north in Norway and encounter even more darkness, people have a significantly more positive winter mindset.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAs the Norwegians like to say, “There’s no such thing as bad weather, only bad clothes.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—\u003cem\u003eNeal Freyman\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n{if profile.signup_time \u003c time(\"-45 days\")}\n{if ! border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Maria Shriver and Patrick Schwarzenegger holding MOSH bars\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/aafed71556bd681c689b155385655748cee796fb-4240x2384.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eInterwoven Media\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen Patrick Schwarzenegger moved back in with his mom, journalist and former First Lady of California Maria Shriver, during the pandemic, they decided to tackle two big projects: 1) watch all of \u003cem\u003eYellowstone\u003c/em\u003e and 2) launch a company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe duo created a brain health brand, \u003ca href=\"https://moshlife.com/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eMOSH\u003c/a\u003e, to educate consumers about the most important part of your body (surprise: It’s not your delts). MOSH launched its first product (and promptly sold out of), protein bars, on September 21—World Alzheimer’s Day—and a portion of the proceeds will be donated to gender-based brain health research.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe chatted with Maria and Patrick about working with family and their new brain food.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy did you decide to launch a snack brand?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMaria:\u003c/em\u003e I've been involved in Alzheimer's research and prevention for two decades, and everywhere that I travel, people always say to me, “Do you have anything to eat? I've read your books, I've seen your documentaries, give me something to eat.” And I'm a protein bar fanatic. But every protein bar gave me a headache or a stomachache. And then my son, who's done a lot of work in the health and wellness space, said, “You should make your own bar to raise money for research and educate people about brain health.” And I was like, oh, I don't think I could do that. I'm too old. And he said, but I'll help you. And here we are.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAre there any other brands you look up to?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ePatrick: \u003c/em\u003eOne of the holy grails, when we were creating this company, was Paul Newman and Newman's Own because he did such a good job of going into different spaces, from salad dressings to lemonade to iced teas to all kinds of different products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat have you learned from working with a family member?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMaria:\u003c/em\u003e I think it's a really great way to learn about what's going on in the world. Working with people who are young keeps you curious, keeps you vital, and keeps you energized. I think Patrick’s generation learns from my generation and vice versa.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIs there a piece of advice you think is outdated in the business world?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ePatrick [to Maria]:\u003c/em\u003e When you first had this idea, a lot of people were saying that no one really cares about the older market, and we don't think that stands true.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMaria: \u003c/em\u003eI think that the boomers—and I'm a boomer—are redefining aging. Madison Avenue, so to speak, has not kept up with who we are and what we want. And so I think that that's a big, huge market\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere is a whole world out there of people who are thriving, working, and creating. Frank Gehry is 97 years of age, and he's designing the most incredible buildings in the world. Warren Buffett is at the top of his game, and he's 91.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/icebreakers-with-maria-shriver-and-patrick-schwarzenegger\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/make-it-work-instilling-better-work-manners?email={{profile.email}}\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\nIs It Bad Etiquette or Bad Performance?\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/make-it-work-instilling-better-work-manners?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make it work image \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new hire started on my team and I'm worried about their etiquette. They leave themselves unmuted on Zoom, often interrupting the speaker, they don't answer when called on by name, they don’t engage during 1:1 trainings, they have poor email communication—you get the picture. How do I go about communicating with them that they need to improve their etiquette, without hurting their feelings?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e–EtiquetteSOS in Los Angeles\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAt first blush, I didn’t think I’d be rolling up my sleeves for this one. As far as the unwritten rules of society are concerned, I typically come up an RSVP late and a dessert fork short. Besides, etiquette guidance is famously Miss Manners’s territory, and I’d like to think I know my place in the advice column universe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe thing is, I’m not convinced that what you’re dealing with here is simply a lack of “etiquette.” If you work in LA, scheduling a late afternoon meeting with an East Coast colleague may be considered poor etiquette. Not being engaged in that meeting, and in fact being disruptive, is a performance issue. Similarly, while we might debate things like the art of the signoff (btw, you’ve inspired my latest, below), generally “poor email communication” is a matter of effectiveness, not merely politeness or convention.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBe it around etiquette or execution, the feedback you provide should be specific and actionable. Avoid making broad characterizations of their behavior (e.g., “disruptive,” “unengaged”) and instead focus on the specific examples that you’ve observed—what did you see? How did it impact the work environment? And what should it look like next time? Not only are you less likely to hurt feelings this way, but you’re also establishing measurable guidelines for what you expect to see going forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt often feels like an uncomfortable reality of leadership, but behavioral coaching is essential to the morale of your team and the preservation of work culture. Left unchecked, you’re likely to find yourself having to navigate more turbulent waters ahead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSOS (Signing off, Shane)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWrite in here\u003c/a\u003e. style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e\nKids At Work\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/05/some-states-are-loosening-child-labor-laws-to-put-younger-teens-to-work?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A scene from Arrested Development, George Michael works in the frozen banana stand\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2aa47dde8a0375096346d06ff818015f00c66394-670x377.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eFOX\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn terms of trends coming back in style this season, we gotta be honest: We were thinking more corduroy, less child labor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAmid hiring and retention woes, US companies have been setting their sights on the youths.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eTeenage employment hit 32% this summer, its highest level \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/law/2021/nov/02/child-labor-laws-weakened-us-industries-teens?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esince 2008\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUnemployment for 16- to 19-year-olds fell below the rate for 20- to 24-year-olds—for the first time in recorded US history.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd lawmakers in several states have been pushing to relax existing child labor laws.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eRelax what now?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eA Wisconsin bill extending the legal working hours of kids ages 14 and 15 was approved by the state Senate in late October. Currently, under the federal Fair Labor Standards Act, these kids are legally permitted to work between 7am and 7pm from Labor Day until May 31, and until 9pm from June 1 until Labor Day. Community pools need their night swim lifeguards, after all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf signed into law, Wisconsin’s SB332 would allow these younger teens to work between 6am and 9:30pm on days preceding school, and between 6am and 11pm on days not preceding school.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eState senators in Ohio introduced a \u003ca href=\"https://legiscan.com/OH/bill/SB251/2021?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esimilar bill\u003c/a\u003e that would allow pre-driving-age teens to work until 9pm during the school year (7pm is the current cutoff).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDon't call it child labor, though:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a 2011 Wisconsin bill replaced all mentions of the term in employment statutes with the nicer-sounding, “employment of minors.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eCritics say the bills are an example of the lengths employers and lawmakers will go to in order to avoid meeting the greater pay demands of the pandemic-era labor force. “Anything but increasing wages,” \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Taniel/status/1452074439978491907?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e journalist Daniel Nichanian.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eIt’s not just the local ice cream shop\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBig names in Corporate America are ramping up the hiring of Americans born post-2005. A Wendy’s franchisee who owns 76 restaurants told the Pennsylvania Tribune that he’s employed about 500 14- and 15-year-olds since the summer. According to Indeed, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.indeed.com/cmp/Wendy's/salaries/Crew-Member?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaverage hourly wage\u003c/a\u003e of a Wendy’s crew member is $9.51.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSigns advertising the hiring of eighth- and ninth graders at McDonald’s locations around the country have \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/business-58414597?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade headlines\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JoshuaPotash/status/1453746545401204740?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1453746545401204740%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_\u0026ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.commondreams.org%2Fnews%2F2021%2F11%2F02%2Frather-pass-wage-increases-gop-legislatures-move-weaken-child-labor-laws\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estruck a nerve\u003c/a\u003e on social media. A sign asking parents if their 14-year-olds “need a job??” posted by a \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/partynextweexnd/status/1392523095450206208?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1392523095450206208%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_\u0026ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Fmcdonalds-trying-to-hire-teens-with-labor-shortage-2021-8\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBurger King\u003c/a\u003e restaurant also went viral (in the bad way).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSupporters of loosening child labor laws cite the value of hard work and how workforce demands are changing when arguing for such measures. In a letter to the Wisconsin State Assembly, a couple who owns three small businesses wrote, “There needs to be some regulation on child labor, but...there needs to be some reconsideration for what is practical, necessary, and realistic.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOn the flip side, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washington.edu/news/2011/02/09/working-more-than-20-hours-a-week-in-high-school-can-harm-grades-uw-researcher-finds/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estudies show\u003c/a\u003e that working 20+ hours a week while in high school can have a negative impact on behavior and academics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDebra Cronmiller, the executive director of the League of Women Voters of Wisconsin, told The Guardian, “The notion that we would be solving some economic turmoil by allowing the expansion of child labor hours is, at best, ridiculous, and at worst, very detrimental to young people.”—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\"
